snippet: Eastern Europe's resistance to taking in migrants is the latest evidence of the stubborn cultural and political divides that persist between East and West.
abstract: Eastern and Central European countries' resistance to taking in refugees hampers European Union efforts to devise unified response to migrant crisis; position of formerly Communist states reflects right-wing and nationalist movements in region as well as prejudice and xenophobia that stand in contrast to 'European values' they pledged to support when joining EU.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Hana de Goeij from Prague; Joanna Berendt from Warsaw; Richard Martyn-Hemphill from Vilnius, Lithuania; Boryana Dzhambazova from Sofia, Bulgaria; and Miroslava Germanova from Bratislava, Slovakia.

lead_paragraph: Eastern Europe's resistance to taking in migrants is the latest evidence of the stubborn cultural and political divides that persist between East and West.

headline.main: Eastern Bloc’s Resistance to Refugees Highlights Europe’s Cultural and Political Divisions
headline.print_headline: Eastern Europe Balking at Aid for Migrants

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
